awd_titl_txt: Fundamental Properties of Micromagnetics for Peripheral and Central Nervous System Stimulation
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent neuroengineering research has demonstrated that motor function and sensing in patients that are affected by neurodegenerative diseases can be partially restored by means of electrical neurostimulation. However, electrode arrays currently used to replace endogenous electrical activation present several drawbacks, including exposure of metal contacts to conductive tissue, potential need for excessive charge density to achieve stimulation when electrode size is small, and lack of tolerance with respect to imperfect contact between the electrode contacts and the neural tissue.
The PIs have recently demonstrated that a new class of microcoils can effectively stimulate the peripheral nervous system, leading to the idea that magnetic microstimulators for implantable devices and neuroprostheses can be devised. Since the mechanisms of magnetic stimulation are centered on eddy currents and their gradients, coils do not need direct contact with the tissue and therefore they can be completely insulated, thus avoiding the possibility of material reactions with conductive neural or surrounding tissues. Further, arrays of coils can potentially offer more options to control the shape of the induced magnetic fields, and therefore eddy currents, and their operation is not affected by contact capacitance. 

Intellectual Merit: The goals of the proposed work capitalize on our theoretical and experimental findings that contact magnetic stimulation of the nervous system is feasible, and investigate new classes of microcoils and magnetic stimulators that will be particularly suited for micromagnetic stimulation. Specifically, a major goal is to investigate coil geometries that allow control of the microcoil?s magnetic fields; this will increase the magnetic flux density levels well beyond those of traditional coils and alter the orientation of the fields in the proximity of the target neurons. Ferrite-backed microcoil arrays have the potential to provide increased field strength, sharp gradients, and control of the magnetic field needed for selective neurostimulation. In this work, the PIs investigate novel devices that could provide a paradigm shift compared to traditional electrical neurostimulators.  

Broader Impacts: This work has the potential to offer a highly innovative solution to peripheral and central system neurostimulation devices. Providing an alternative solution to surface or penetrating electrodes could positively impact a number of implantable systems, which currently suffer from the significant drawbacks of electrical neural stimulation. Besides the important clinical impact, the proposed program offers unique opportunities to train engineering students in a highly interdisciplinary activity at the forefront of engineering technology and medical research. In addition to utilizing the proposed research activity in various existing programs designed to have a lasting impact on current and prospective undergraduate students, the proposed project will increase the interest of engineering students in the emerging field of neuroprosthetics and demonstrate the benefits of engineering to medicine. The PIs will provide additional learning opportunities targeted at K-12, 2-year, and 4-year feeder schools and colleges through outreach programs.

por.por_cntn:
Stimulation of the brain and peripheral nerves has been proven to provide relief for many disorders of the nervous system, including controlling Parkinsonian tremors with deep brain stimulation and restoring a sense of hearing with cochlear implants. To date, the primary stimulation method has been electrical but this method also has drawbacks, such as those associated with the necessary metal to tissue interface. Magnetic stimulation has been proposed as an alternative; however, magnetic stimulation has not yet been widely accepted due to the relative large size of the magnetic stimulators and high energy levels that are necessary to evoke a neural response, especially in the case of the motor system. Recent research has prompted efforts to revisit this by reporting the ability to magnetically stimulate brain tissue with very small coils and with less than one volt of stimulation intensity. The primary thrust of this project was to seek solutions to reduce the size of coils and lower energy levels required to stimulate peripheral nerves, directed toward restoring muscle movement in individuals with paralysis, for example, and other use cases.

In this program, we substantively decreased the size of the simulating coils, by a factor of ~10 compared to the state-of-the-art in peripheral magnetic neurostimulation, and decreased the energy requirements for effective stimulation, by a factor of ~10 as well, to the point that it is feasible to now consider implanting stimulating coils. In fact, through this work, we developed coils small enough to be implanted in rats: these coils were successfully used for peripheral neurostimulation of the sciatic nerve, with heat associated to the operation of the coils that was within acceptable range (less than 2 degrees C). This improvement is primarily due to (1) novel computational models of functional magnetic stimulation that allowed identifying promising stimulating coil designs and stimulation electronics with a computer instead of via many animals; (2) in-vivo testing and verification of the performance of stimulating coil designs that are as effective as traditional coils but smaller; and (3) adapting stimulating hardware from transcranial magnetic stimulation that stops electrical current flow after neural excitation occurs, instead of allowing current to flow without further efficacious neural excitation which is a cause of potentially damaging heating.

Having made significant progress toward developing a practical method of magnetically stimulating peripheral nerve, we additionally investigated the ability to selectively stimulate subregions of the nerve, which would allow us to evoke functionally useful stimulation such as that associated to restoring walking gait. Our computer simulations show that we can reliably and controllably evoke activity in specific parts of the nerve by using a pair of coils, or arrays of coils; further, simulations reveal that we can change which parts of the nerve are stimulated by controlling the current in each of the coils of the array. Future work consists in the validation of this concept as well as further miniaturization of the devices and stimulating unit so as to render implantable magnetic stimulation a viable alternative to traditional electrical stimulation.
